awd_titl_txt: MRI:  Offshore Earthquake Monitoring at Subduction Zones Using Autonomous Underwater Vehicles and High-Speed Optical Telemetry For Data Retrieval
awd_abstract_narration:
The earth's subduction zones, where one tectonic plate overrides another, are the sites of the planet's largest and most dangerous earthquakes. Recent examples are the 2004 magnitude 9.1 Sumatra and the 2010 magnitude 9 Tohoku, Japan earthquakes. In addition to massive destruction brought about by ground shaking, both of these earthquakes generated devastating tsunamis. These events are a reminder that fault motion in our planet's largest earthquakes happens offshore under the continental shelf, a region that is challenging to monitor. The scarcity of seismic instrumentation in the source regions of these great earthquakes has limited the seismological community's ability to answer fundamental scientific questions and to evaluate hazards in real-time. Sustained offshore monitoring of subduction zones would not only lead to improved understanding of these faults but also potentially allow the identification of increased short-term risk. Extensive foreshock sequences located far offshore preceded both the 2010 Tohoku event and the recent 2014 magnitude 9 Pisagua Chile earthquake. These sequences demonstrated that there are detectable time periods on the scale of weeks when subduction zones are more likely to produce a large rupture. To fully understand this basic fault behavior and possibly utilize an understanding of it to reduce risk, rapid access to high quality seismic data from offshore directly above the great earthquakes is needed. 
 
The seismological community routinely deploys seismographs offshore, but data access requires ship-based instrument recovery, a lengthy and expensive task that may not be possible or desirable during a potential foreshock sequence. Seismology is a fast moving science: earthquakes are detected within seconds, magnitude estimates are tweeted within minutes, fault planes are determined within hours, and research articles are often submitted within weeks of a major earthquake.  The full potential of offshore seismic data can only be realized if these data are rapidly ingested into data centers. Recent advances at Woods Hole Oceanographic Institution in optical telemetry and marine robotics, coupled with the availability of commercial off-the-shelf low-power seismic sensors, data loggers and atomic clocks offer the capability for multi-year deployments of arrays of ocean-bottom seismographs (OBS) that are capable of delivering high-frequency, accurately-timed seismic data to shore with data latencies of hours to days without OBS recovery. This project will develop such a system by integrating a WHOI-designed optical modem capable of telemetry rates of 20 Mbits/second with an OBS and with a long-range (up to 286 nautical miles) REMUS Autonomous Underwater Vehicle (AUV). These proven rates allow telemetry of a week of high-rate (100 Hz) seismic data on 4 channels (ground motion and pressure) in minutes (or a year of data in less than 2 hours). Moreover, accurate timing is critical for earthquake location but OBS lack the benefit of GPS timing. The optical link will also allow measurement of the offset of the OBS clock relative to a GPS-synchronized time signal carried by the AUV to a precision of ~1 microsecond. These technologies will make possible multi-year deployments of OBS arrays with on-demand data offload and clock-check without the need for annual recovery/re-deployment cruises, saving hundreds of thousands of dollars per experiment. This capability will be particularly suitable for the dense near-shore arrays needed to monitor subduction zones.

por.por_cntn:
The goal of this project was to develop and demonstrate a data mule for seafloor seismology using a WHOI REMUS Autonomous Underwater Vehicle (AUV) as the mule, a WHOI optical modem as the high-rate telemetry technology, and a WHOI Ocean Bottom Seismograph (OBS) as the source of seismic data. The long-term vision is to develop an earthquake monitoring system capable of delivering to shore high-rate, accurately-timed seismic data from an array of OBS with data latencies of hours to days only. WHOI?s optical modem technology allows telemetry of a year of 100 Hz data on 4 channels (ground motion and pressure) in less than 9 hours, or a week of such data in about 10 minutes. Accurate timing is critical for earthquake location, and the optical link allows measurement of the offset of the OBS clock relative to a GPS-synchronized time signal carried by the AUV to a precision of ~1 microsecond. Low-power sensors and data-loggers now allow OBS deployments to be extended to 2 years without greatly increasing battery size. Thus, it is practical to envision multi-year deployments of OBS arrays with on-demand data offload and clock-check without the need for annual OBS recovery/re-deployment cruises. The capability will be particularly suitable for near-shore, closely spaced (km?10?s of km) seismic arrays deployed on the continental shelf and slope immediately above a subduction zone.  This would allow monitoring of seismicity on the subduction zone interface, regions that generate the world?s largest and most destructive earthquakes and tsunamis.

We integrated optical modems with an Ocean Bottom Seismograph (OBS) and with a REMUS-600 Autonomous Underwater Vehicle (AUV), and carried out two successful field tests of the entire system.  For our last and most demanding field test, the AUV swam 25 nautical miles to an OBS that we deployed south of Martha's Vineyard, located the OBS, and offloaded ~177 MBytes of seismic data while simultaneously measuring the offset of the OBS clock relative to the clock on the AUV.  The AUV then swam 25 nautical miles back to its recovery location. The entire operation from AUV launch, to locating the OBS, to data extraction and OBS clock-check, and finally to AUV recovery took place entirely autonomously, other than status updates from the vehicle via Iridium and acoustics.

For the Martha's Vineyard test, the AUV travelled at ~3 knots.  While offloading data from the OBS, the AUV achieved a loiter radius about the OBS of ~10 m.  Data offload rate was 3.7 Mbits/s.  This rate is high, but lower than advertised, possibly due to scattering by biota in these shallow (35 m) waters.  Other local AUV runs achieved data offload rates of 3.6, 2.8, 2.4, and 3.7 Mbits/s.  The lower rates are associated with AUV loiter paths deliberately not centered on the OBS, During data offload the offset between reference clock and the OBS clock is recorded roughly every 4 seconds.   This also allows an estimate of the drift-rate of the OBS clock, not just the drift.

We have demonstrated that an AUV can be used as a seismic "data-mule" and deliver timing to an OBS.  This opens up the possibility of an AUV harvesting high-rate seismic data from an array of closely-spaced OBS deployed on the shelf and slope above a subduction zone.  AUVs such as the REMUS AUV are now being designed/built with substantially greater transit and on-site endurance.  Capabilities such as offloading data from the AUV to a Liquid Robotics glider are now being explored.  These developments enhance the data-mule concept.

The rates achieved by the optical modem (3.7 Mbits/s) contrasts with the 100-200 bits/s achieved by the acoustically-linked moored buoy observatory deployed 80 km offshore Vancouver Island in 2004/2005.  A broadband OBS digitizing 4 channels (3 x seismometer, 1 x pressure) at a sampling rate of 100 Hz records ~40 Mbytes/day (compressed) or ~280 MBytes/week.  At 3.7 Mbits/s, a week of data would be offloaded in ~10 minutes.  Imagine a 24-station OBS array with 20 km inter-station distance deployed offshore Cascadia, i.e. a 300 nautical mile path.  It would take ~4 hours to offload a week of data from the entire array. At AUV transit speed of 3 knots, the entire mission would take just 4.5 days.  A dedicated AUV could run this mission every week.
